009package imagingbook.common.geometry.fitting.ellipse.algebraic;
010
011import static imagingbook.common.math.Arithmetic.sqr;
012
013import org.apache.commons.math3.linear.MatrixUtils;
014import org.apache.commons.math3.linear.RealMatrix;
015
016import imagingbook.common.geometry.basic.Pnt2d;
017import imagingbook.common.geometry.basic.PntUtils;
018import imagingbook.common.math.Matrix;
019import imagingbook.common.math.eigen.GeneralizedSymmetricEigenDecomposition;
020
021/**
022 * <p>
023 * Algebraic ellipse fit based on Taubin's method [1]. Version 1 uses the full
024 * scatter and constraint matrix (6x6), the solution is found by a generalized
025 * symmetric eigendecomposition. Note that the constraint matrix (C) is not
026 * positive definite. See [3, Sec. 11.2.1] for a detailed description (Alg.
027 * 11.7). This implementation performs data centering or, alternatively, accepts
028 * a specific reference point.
029 * <p>
030 * [1] G. Taubin, G. Taubin. "Estimation of planar curves, surfaces, and
031 * nonplanar space curves defined by implicit equations with applications to
032 * edge and range image segmentation", IEEE Transactions on Pattern Analysis and
033 * Machine Intelligence 13(11), 1115â€“1138 (1991). <br>
034 * [2] W. Burger, M.J. Burge, <em>Digital Image Processing &ndash; An
035 * Algorithmic Introduction</em>, 3rd ed, Springer (2022).
036 * </p>
037 * 
038 * @author WB
039 * @version 2021/11/09
040 * @see EllipseFitTaubin2
041 */
042public class EllipseFitTaubin1 implements EllipseFitAlgebraic {
043        
044        private final double[] q;       // = (A,B,C,D,E,F) ellipse parameters
045        
046        public EllipseFitTaubin1(Pnt2d[] points, Pnt2d xref) {
047                if (points.length < 5) {
048                        throw new IllegalArgumentException("at least 5 points must be supplied for ellipse fitting");
049                }
050                this.q = fit(points, xref);
051                
052        }
053        
054        public EllipseFitTaubin1(Pnt2d[] points) {
055                this(points, PntUtils.centroid(points));
056        }
057
058        @Override
059        public double[] getParameters() {
060                return this.q;
061        }
062        
063        // --------------------------------------------------------------------------
064        
065        private double[] fit(Pnt2d[] points, Pnt2d xref) {
066                final int n = points.length;
067                
068                // reference point
069                final double xr = xref.getX();
070                final double yr = xref.getY();
071
072                // design matrix (same as Fitzgibbon):
073                RealMatrix X = MatrixUtils.createRealMatrix(n, 6);
074                for (int i = 0; i < n; i++) {
075                        final double x = points[i].getX() - xr; // center data set
076                        final double y = points[i].getY() - yr;
077                        double[] fi = {sqr(x), x*y, sqr(y), x, y, 1};
078                        X.setRow(i, fi);
079                }
080                
081                // scatter matrix S (normalized by 1/n)
082                RealMatrix S = X.transpose().multiply(X).scalarMultiply(1.0/n);
083                        
084                double a = S.getEntry(0, 5);
085                double b = S.getEntry(2, 5);
086                double c = S.getEntry(1, 5);    //2*s[1][5];
087                double d = S.getEntry(3, 5);
088                double e = S.getEntry(4, 5);
089                
090                // constraint matrix
091                RealMatrix C = Matrix.makeRealMatrix(6, 6, 
092                                4*a, 2*c, 0,   2*d, 0,   0 , 
093                                2*c, a+b, 2*c, e,   d,   0 , 
094                                0,   2*c, 4*b, 0,   2*e, 0 , 
095                                2*d, e,   0,   1,   0,   0 ,
096                                0,   d,   2*e, 0,   1,   0 , 
097                                0,   0,   0,   0,   0,   0 );
098                
099                // solve C*p = lambda*S*p (note: C is not positive definite!)
100                GeneralizedSymmetricEigenDecomposition eigen = 
101                                new GeneralizedSymmetricEigenDecomposition(C, S, 1e-15, 1e-15); 
102                
103                double[] evals = eigen.getRealEigenvalues();
104                
105                int k = Matrix.idxMax(evals);   // index of largest eigenvalue
106                double[] qopt = eigen.getEigenvector(k).toArray();
107                
108                RealMatrix U = getDataOffsetCorrectionMatrix(xr, yr);
109                return U.operate(qopt);
110        }
111}
